title: Nvidia, Victoria's Secret, Rivian, Macy's: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today; Victoria's Secret shares gained after its earnings report; A pair of electric-vehicle startups were ticking lower premarket
text:
* Shares of Victoria's Secret climbed 11% premarket after the lingerie retailer topped earnings forecasts for the recent quarter.

* Cisco Systems dropped 5.7% premarket. The networking company gave a weaker-than-expected outlook for the second quarter.

* Electric-vehicle startups Lucid Group and Rivian Automotive were slipping for a second day after a recent run-up in their stock prices, by 6.5% and 5.5% respectively. But heavyweight Tesla was still on the rise, adding 1.4%.

* Chinese e-commerce giants Alibaba and JD.com were charting separate courses premarket after their earnings reports. U.S.-traded shares of JD.com added 0.9% after it posted a net loss but with higher revenue. Alibaba dropped 4% after it said its profit fell for the recent quarter due to losses arising from changes in prices for its equity investments in publicly traded companies.

* Kohl's shares jumped 8.5% premarket after the department store retailer reported third-quarter record earnings that beat expectations.

* Macy's soared 12% after it said it would launch a new digital marketplace.

* BJ's Wholesale Club gained 3.5% after it posted stronger-than-expected earnings for its third quarter and said its board has approved a share buyback program of up to $500 million.

* Deere added 1.3% premarket. Workers at the farm and construction machinery company ratified a new six-year contract Wednesday, ending a strike that lasted over a month.

* Bath & Body Works gained 4.9%. The retailer reported lower earnings and sales in its first quarterly results as a stand-alone business, but said it expects to record higher fourth-quarter earnings than a year earlier.

* Intuit, Workday, Applied Materials, Ross Stores and Palo Alto Networks will give updates after the close.

Chart of the Day

* Banks are spending big on mailers and generous rewards to lure cardholders and get them borrowing again.

Write to James Willhite at james.willhite@wsj.com
